definition: Six Methods of forming Chinese characters, according to Han dictionary Shuowen 說文|说文 - namely, two primary methods: 象形 (pictogram), 指事 (ideogram), two compound methods: 會意|会意 (combined ideogram), 形聲|形声 (ideogram plus phonetic), and two transfer methods: 假借 (loan), 轉注|转注 (transfer)
six/6
abbr. for 書經|书经[Shu1 jing1]
book/letter/document/CL:本[ben3],冊|册[ce4],部[bu4]/to write

sentences.english: Introduce character-making principles and six categories of Chinese characters.
sentences.chinese: 依汉字结构，介绍造字原理与六书内涵。

sentences.english: Transcription is one of the six categories of traditional structural theory of Chinese characters.
sentences.chinese: 转注是传统汉字结构理论的“六书”之一。

sentences.english: In ancient China, Chinese characters were made according to six categories.
sentences.chinese: 中国古代透过六书的方法造字。

sentences.english: Six books, most recently Invention of Air.
Fourth, explaining the principle about Liushu and shuowen.
sentences.chinese: 第四，系统地阐发六书与《说文》的条例。

sentences.english: There will be a briefing book six but very creative and dynamic websites.
sentences.chinese: 是一个能有介绍六书但却很有创造力及活力的网站。

definition: to interpret and make glossaries and commentaries on classic texts
ideogram (one of the Six Methods 六書|六书 of forming Chinese characters)/Chinese character indicating an idea, such as up and down/also known as self-explanatory character
philology
Shuowen Jiezi, the original Han dynasty Chinese character dictionary with 10,516 entries, authored by Xu Shen 許慎|许慎[Xu3 Shen4] in 2nd century
character book (i.e. school primer)
inscription in bronze/bell-cauldron inscription
Commentary on Shuowen Jiezi (1815) by Duan Yucai 段玉裁[Duan4 Yu4 cai2]
study of classic texts, including interpretation, glossaries and commentaries
Xu Shen (-147) the compiler of the original Han dynasty dictionary Shuowen Jiezi 說文解字|说文解字[Shuo1 wen2 Jie3 zi4]
old language/the Classics/Classical Chinese as a literary model, esp. in Tang and Song prose/Classical Chinese as a school subject
ideogram plus phonetic (one of the Six Methods 六書|六书 of forming Chinese characters)/also known as phonogram, phonetic compound or picto-phonetic character
the small or lesser seal, the form of Chinese character standardized by the Qin dynasty
to explain/to interpret/interpretation
to create Chinese characters/cf Six Methods of forming Chinese characters 六書|六书[liu4 shu1]
Shizhoupian, early school primer in great seal script 大篆[da4 zhuan4], attributed to King Xuan of Zhou 周宣王[Zhou1 Xuan1 wang2] but probably dating from c. 500 BC
the great seal/used narrowly for 籀文/used broadly for many pre-Qin scripts
